text.text: Welcome to the Accessibility & Inclusion Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored outline of two people on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 Accessibility & Inclusion Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events for the Accessibility & Inclusion Digital Lounge on the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=e6qkynl0| Apple Developer app and on  developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
Hi everyone! Welcome to our *Accessibility Icebreaker*—thanks for joining us today! Hope you’ve been having an amazing WWDC so far. My name’s J and I’m on the Accessibility team at Apple, and today I’m joined by a bunch of awesome folks also working on Accessibility. Throughout the next hour I’ll be starting up a few messages on this channel, and you’re welcome to start the conversation with a response in the threads! We’re all looking forward to learning more about the ways you’ve been making software more accessible, and all the things that you’re particularly excited about this week.

Very excited to chat with you all today!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When I’m in dark room and my toddler is going to sleep, my phone shines too bright even when the screen is set to the dimmest. I thought why the phone couldn’t be darker just by making whites go more and more gray. I found white point reduction under Accessibility, which does exactly what I need :blush: I use it almost daily now.

messages.text: Is there an accomplishment (or even bug!) that you are most proud of addressing/fixing when making your app accessible?

elements.text: Is there an accomplishment (or even bug!) that you are most proud of addressing/fixing when making your app accessible?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Committing to make our apps accessible, me and a colleague used our iPhones with screen reader and many other features, we did catch lots of bugs by actually knowing how people use their devices with different accessibility functions

I now have a screen reader with a quick shortcut , it's very useful when wanting to read content quickly at a high speed , or if I want to just use my phone without looking at the screen when my eyes are strained :yawning_face:

Not an accomplishment really but something I really enjoy: I find improving Dynamic Type support with the largest accessibility sizes super fun. Tweaking and providing alternative layouts to better accomodate text with larger font sizes really improves the experience.

Bug! I recently found a VoiceOver focus trap. Never seen one before! Swipe right would land on an element, swipe right again and it would go to the previous one. It turns out there was a button with an icon to the right of the text. To achieve that, the button was forced to be right-to-left, and that little hack was causing the bug.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ah yeah, forcing things to be RTL or LTR can lead to unintended behaviour—always interested in collecting feedback about that as well!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: My very first app was accessible, and I won an award from the MTA for it. On that note, the framing "making your app accessible" is very unhelpful, specifically "your app". The people watching WWDC talks aren't usually the product owner. Making an app accessible is a product decision, and requires product and design decision-making.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If I have any "feedback theme" for this WWDC, it's that the people Apple employees are interacting with aren't usually the decision-makers on implementing this features -- legitimately. Haranguing developers from the stage "you should make *your app* accessible" isn't it, because the people you are addressing overwhelmingly aren't the app product owners.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Totally sympathize with this sentiment, lots of apps are built by large teams of people with tons of moving parts! There are always tons of really simple and straightforward things you can do to make your app more accessible though, that won't require changes from product or design. Something as simple as setting the right accessibilityLabel goes a long way, and takes just a few seconds. :slightly_smiling_face: And the more you learn about the accessibility the more tools you have to bring back to your designers and product owners to convince them to invest more in this space, so we hope the information is worthwhile.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yeah, it's just more - when trying to get more people interested in implementing accessibility, the messaging can certainly improve - not only "here's what you can do (say, setting accessibilityLabel) but also here's WHY and what you can pass onto the rest of your team if you have one", or... I don't know what else might work, but as someone who does work in accessibility too, there can be a lot of different departments who might not see it as a value.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: that's not an accessibility API issue per se, that's more getting people to realize how important things like that are, and getting buy-in on why accessibility is important in the first place. Having the accessibility APIs and hooks HELP from there. But it affects all these other things that we often think of as their own fields (information architecture, QA, development workflow, etc) as well and that can actually be counterproductive to think of it as a separate thing ^^;

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Yes <@U03JK0YMKLL> I realized this when watching accessible charts last year. In order to make accessible charts, you need to use their very highly organized chart data structures... and as they are very thought through, really everyone could be using those. First conceptualize the data you need, then render it into visual UI or audio UI. I am called it "Accessible-First Design". The idea that conceptualizing your UI and data structures for accessibility first will make designing your visual UI easy with those same data structures.

Saying "the devs should just know how to do use these APIs to make things accessible by themselves" is not helpful.

messages.text: What do you think are the ingredients to making an amazing, accessible app?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would say the main ingredient is to test your app. Try to accomplish important tasks in your app with different technologies like VoiceOver. But the most important thing: listen to your users! :smiley:

elements.text: I would say the main ingredient is to test your app. Try to accomplish important tasks in your app with different technologies like VoiceOver. But the most important thing: listen to your users!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I agree. I also think that having the mindshift to think about accessability as a feature for everyone goes far.

elements.text: I agree. I also think that having the mindshift to think about accessability as a feature for everyone goes far.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Features that bring value to the user. We're working on adding more audio content to our app and dynamic type for example. When I wake up in the am, small font size on iPhone is challenging to read but the dynamic type helps a lot. I'm near-sighted and have good vision, but this larger font tool is very helpful. So applying the available tools to support easy use of the device is a win win.

messages.text: What advice would you give to new developers on making their new app or project accessible?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for asking this! Really interested in the answers.

elements.text: Thanks for asking this! Really interested in the answers.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For me the biggest thing is considering and building in good accessibility from the beginning. It’s sooo much easier than trying to add it on after

elements.text: For me the biggest thing is considering and building in good accessibility from the beginning. It’s sooo much easier than trying to add it on after

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think a lot of developers can feel a bit overwhelmed when starting to learn about accessibility, so I sometimes suggest to start with VoiceOver. Because having a good VoiceOver experience, doesn't guarantee, but tends to get you most of the way there to offer a good experience for Switch Control, Voice Control, of Full Keyboard Access. But again, do it from the beginning, test it yourself on a real device, and listen to your users! :grin:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think these are all really great tips—totally agree about making sure there's a system for listening & collecting feedback! Software can only truly be accessible if everybody is involved.

One tip (I believe by Sommer Panage) that I liked was to look at how the system (iOS but also Android) handles things for VoiceOver for example. That way you can do the same and keep the user experience predictable.

messages.text: How are you infusing accessibility into your organization?

elements.text: How are you infusing accessibility into your organization?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I call it the snowball effect. One day you make some comments on a PR that hasn't made a feature accessible, or that could be improved in some way. Some other day, that other developer asks you a questions about it for his next task. Later on, you see him discussing accessibility with a third colleague. It is about getting the ball rolling!

Devs are usually amazed to see how a couple lines of code made a massive difference in the experience, showing that accessibility isn't as difficult as they may think.

And demo something you've done, or an improvement you've made, at every possible opportunity to the rest of the team! :muscle:

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Totally agree with <@U03J20KLXH9> , just making steady progress and talking about accessibility or even demoing new features you're working on with assistive tech helps make people more aware of accessibility!

I've also found that SwiftUI unlocks some potential for static analysis to catch accessibility issues at compile time and have been working on some SwiftLint rules that my org and others can adopt! The <https://http://realm.github.io/SwiftLint/accessibility_label_for_image.htmlrule|accessibility_label_for_image> rule can catch when an Image doesn't have a label (and isn't hidden from accessibility), and have an open PR for <https://github.com/realm/SwiftLint/pull/3989|accessibility_trait_for_button> to catch when tap gestures are added without the button or link trait. Any and all feedback is welcome and I hope to see these rules adopted more widely!

messages.text: Last question for today’s icebreaker! Is there something you’ve learned this year when it comes to accessibility or making software accessible?

elements.text: Last question for today’s icebreaker! Is there something you’ve learned this year when it comes to accessibility or making software accessible?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If it doesn't affect you, it can be really difficult to think of it as necessary. But 1 out of 5 (actually more, numbers vary, and due to the pandemic we are seeing more people dealing with chronic illness) people worldwide deal with some kind of disability. So even if you look at the numbers, it doesn't make sense to ignore accessibility or to put it off.

elements.text: If it doesn't affect you, it can be really difficult to think of it as necessary. But 1 out of 5 (actually more, numbers vary, and due to the pandemic we are seeing more people dealing with chronic illness) people worldwide deal with some kind of disability. So even if you look at the numbers, it doesn't make sense to ignore accessibility or to put it off.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That also means accessibility isn't an "out there" issue; a lot of people don't think of Siri as an accessibility tool, but for a lot of people it is (for example those with mobility issues), even if they don't identify as disabled. They may say they have an old injury or arthritis or things like that, too.

messages.text:
Hello everyone and welcome to Meet the Presenter for the session *Add accessibility to your Unity games*

We’re incredibly excited to have you with us today to watch the session and chat with us about the accessibility Unity plug-in.

I’m Eric, an engineer from accessibility team and the speaker from today's session. I'm also joined by a bunch of awesome folks also working on accessibility.

This activity is a watch party followed by a discussion and Q&A after the video completes. As the video progresses I’ll be creating threads for each section of the talk where everyone in the channel can chat and react.

After the video has finished playing please stick around for the discussion and Q&A! First, I will post some prompt questions and you’re welcome to start the conversation with a response in the threads. Then we will enable a slack workflow that allows you to submit any questions that you might have and we'll do our best to answer. (To ask a question, click the plus button (:heavy_plus_sign:) in the lower left of the chat, then find the "Ask a Question" lightning bolt.)

In order to sync up with everyone and watch together, we'll synchronize our video start time to *02:05 PM PT*. I'll give a message to let you know when I'm kicking off the video on my end.

Thanks for joining!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Klayton, a lot of this likely starts at the design stage. The best high-level recommendation we tend to give is to allow for any given label in a design to grow significantly, both in content and in size. In many cases this involves making content scrollable, or adapting horizontal layouts to become vertical at a particular text size. For the latter, I highly recommend checking out ViewThatFits, which is a new view in SwiftUI this year that lets you specify variations of views, allowing the framework to pick the best one depending on the available size.

I’ve also got some links that I highly recommend checking out if you haven’t already: an app challenge from last year, a couple WWDC sessions, as well as the “Text display” section in our Human Interface Guidelines.

If you have specific questions about making sure your app works great with Dynamic Type we’d be happy to answer those too!

<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2017/245/>
<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10020/>
<https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/accessibility#text-display>

We have an exciting event at 4PM PDT today - The Accessibility Community Panel.

We’re going to be talking to a few members of the accessibility engineering and quality teams to discuss how they use assistive technologies, the impact it’s made on them, as well as what motivates them.

I have some topics lined up and then we can open up the floor to more questions

Let me call out our panel members and invite them to say a few words on their background and what kind of assistive tech they use at Apple.

Hi everyone! :wave::skin-tone-2: I'm Dan and I've worked on the accessibility team for the past 5 years here at Apple. Primarily I work on vision accessibility features, like VoiceOver, Zoom, Speak Screen, and other text to speech related technologies. I work mostly on our embedded platforms, like iOS, tvOS, and watchOS.

I am a low vision user myself. I started using Apple products in school and once I found Zoom I was hooked! I begged my parents to buy me a mac and have used Apple products ever since. I use things like Zoom, Large Text, and Magnifier all the time to work and in my personal life, so it's really fun to be working on technologies that I use on a daily basis! Happy to chat about anything anyone wants to know!

messages.text: *Question 1:* What has a specific Assistive Technology allowed you to do in your school or professional life that you wouldn’t have been able to do otherwise?

elements.text: What has a specific Assistive Technology allowed you to do in your school or professional life that you wouldn’t have been able to do otherwise?

elements.text: do you want to answer first?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So I’ve been using VoiceOver now for nearly 20 years. It is indeed that old, as it was originally introduced as Spoken User Interface Public Preview. I used that beta software to complete my college degree as my eye sight was moving from low vision to blind, which also took a nearly 20 year transition. Before that, it was CloseView if anyone remembers that one from classic Mac OS. I’ve been at Apple now for nearly 15 years, and VoiceOver continues to be my method of conducting both my professional work, and my personal life.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I started my career as a mathematician working in neuroscience. The lack of assistive technology to read scientific publications and work with computers at the time, made me pivot into software development with the goal to help advance accessibility to the digital universe for millions o people like myself. I could not work as a scientist or as an engineer without assistive technology and accessible software.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Technology has truly come such a long way. I used to have gigantic textbooks as a child. They'd cut off the spine of the book and print them on huge paper and in multiple volumes. I stood out as a kid for sure and had to lug really heavy books and magnifiers back and forth to school. I always had to have a seat in the front row. By the time I got to college, I could snap a quick photo of the board with my iPhone, and all my textbooks were eBooks or PDFs. And zoom on my mac allowed me to access things the same way everyone else would.

The one moment that sticks out to me was learning how to type. We were playing this game in school that taught you how to type and it was space themed. Letters would float by your spaceship and you had to type them as they flew in. I couldn't see the letters so I was really struggling, and a teacher showed me Zoom on OS X (I think it was Panther at the time). My eyes widened as I could finally play the game and learn to type. I had used Magnifier on windows PCs before but always found it clunky and hard to use, and what OS X offered was a game changer for me. It truly opened up opportunities for me. Now I use zoom every day to get my work done and write code, I can't imagine life without it.

Hello,
The two features that have drastically changed my life personally are Switch Control and Voice Control. Because i am physically challenged, I would not be able to use my Apple device at all while I’m out on the go whether it is in my car, shopping, at dinner, or  hanging out with friends.

I use Voice Control simultaneously for texting and to perform quicker actions that may take longer with Switch Control.

messages.text: *Question 2:* What are you most excited about in these upcoming software releases for iOS/macOS/tvOS and watchOS?

elements.text: What are you most excited about in these upcoming software releases for iOS/macOS/tvOS and watchOS?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HW63MVRP> and <@U03JUND0CJE>?

I’m definitely most excited about HoverText coming to tvOS. Zoom on Apple TV is fantastic, but when sitting far away, I usually have to magnify the content to be pretty large, and it’s easy to lose your place or quickly browse a list of content because when content is magnified at that large a scale, you can see so little of it. While I am totally team zoom on my Mac, I think HoverText is going to be super great for browsing content on Apple TV, especially when selecting shows or movies to watch with friends, since it doesn’t require gestures for them to learn.

I’m also really excited about all the new languages we are support in Text to Speech this year. This is going to open up our products to so many more users, and I am really happy to see that.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
We really had a breakthrough with People Detection. I’m excited that we’re continuing the development of detection mode and adding Door Detection for the fall release. This truely is the combination of optics, LiDAR, machine learning, reduced down to something easy to use that can be enabled in a flash the moment you need it.

With People Detection, it was possible to walk into a crowded coffee shop and find a quiet empty space to wait for an online pickup. With Door Detection, it will now be possible to find not just the door, but nearby signage that will help identify it as being the correct door, the one you actually wanted to find. Being able to do this in an instant, with just my phone in my pocket, that’s something incredibly special.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HHGBCX99>?

I have very much appreciated all of the incredible feedback we have received so far on our new text to speech voices. We’re not just making text to speech available in more languages than ever before, but we also are introducing Eloquence. Eloquence has been requested from many customers, the main reason being many people have spent a literal lifetime hearing that speech engine. Being able to listen at incredibly high speeds by training your brain for many years on a voice is critical to screen reader proficiency. To many, it will sound like an old robot, but to so many others, it is a voice perhaps so familiar that when heard it fades away in their consciousness, replaced by the pure meaning of the material being heard at those incredibly high speeds.

messages.text: *Question 3:* What would you want developers to know about accessible technology?

elements.text: What would you want developers to know about accessible technology?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HW63MVRP> and <@U03HAU1SFFY>?

I want them to know that a little bit of effort goes SUCH a long way. When I open an app and it has large support I breathe a huge sigh of relief. Apps are orders of magnitude easier to use when I can read the text without squinting or using zoom. Just a little bit of engineering effort can truly change how people interact with your app or your company, and open up a world of opportunities. As corny as it sounds, Apple introducing Zoom on the Mac truly changed my life, and completely changed how I access information and navigate throughout the world. Putting these small details in like large text or adding VoiceOver support is the difference between someone getting true value out of your app and giving them worlds of opportunities, and being completely cut off from the value your app provides . Talk to people in the community! Talk to users of the app you’re working on if you can see what frustrations they are experiencing first hand. With just a few quick fixes you can make such an impact.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U03HHGBL8TV> and <@U03HHGBCX99>?

I’d say sticking to best practices really goes a long way. Following the HIG, working through our material on making accessible apps etc, will almost always result in the best experience for the most people. Sometimes you have to do something custom but those cases should be rare. Our accessibility technologies work best when apps follow these principles.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
When you create an app, you might not realize that you’re actually creating a potential for somebody to do something that isn’t just convenience, but might be utterly life-changing. When you create a delivery app, you’re providing an opportunity for somebody to be able to gather meals or items that would otherwise be incredibly challenging to procure. When your banking application is fully accessible, you provide somebody financial independence. When your Health application is fully accessible, the responsibility and decision-making lands in the hands of the person who needs to make the most of it. When you create accessible games, you provide a source of entertainment and camaraderie that can enrich lives. When you make your creative applications, such as music, DJ, painting, video editing, and more fully accessible, you’re providing an opportunity for somebody to express themselves in a way they never thought possible.

All of these things are possible, with your apps, today, as long as you spend a bit of time to make sure that you implement accessibility. Some of it comes for free, but much of it does require your creative and innovative brainstorming to make it work the best.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The Switch Control and Voice Control are the two main Accessibility features I use, which happened to heavily rely upon App Accessibility. While there are work arounds to navigate in accessible apps, they take a lot longer to navigate a  not so accessible app.

My advice to developers is to use the Accessibility API when developing your app because you inherit a lot of the Accessibility feature support for free. If you’re doing custom UI, please ensure that the element order is correct, and buttons, images and other key elements are properly labeled.

If you’re unsure about how to go about making your app properly accessible, I highly recommend that you check out the built in app tool in Xcode called the Accessibility inspector.

The Switch Control and Voice Control are the two main Accessibility features I use, which happened to heavily rely upon App Accessibility. While there are work arounds to navigate in accessible apps, they take a lot longer to navigate a  not so accessible app.

My advice to developers is to use the Accessibility API when developing your app because you inherit a lot of the Accessibility feature support for free. If you’re doing custom UI, please ensure that the element order is correct, and buttons, images and other key elements are properly labeled.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Also, if you feel that it is important to use a cross platform software development kit, investigate the accessibility of that package before you choose to make it your foundation. Many cross platform SDKs that are popular today may not necessarily provide an optimal experience, and may require incredible amounts of extra work, if it is even possible, in order to make your app ready for accessibility.

elements.text: Also, if you feel that it is important to use a cross platform software development kit, investigate the accessibility of that package before you choose to make it your foundation. Many cross platform SDKs that are popular today may not necessarily provide an optimal experience, and may require incredible amounts of extra work, if it is even possible, in order to make your app ready for accessibility.

messages.text:
<@U03J9D6803X> asked
> What are some example scenarios of where you could tell a developer tried to meet your accessibility needs but missed something?  Are there patterns?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What are some example scenarios of where you could tell a developer tried to meet your accessibility needs but missed something?  Are there patterns?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yeah, as a low vision user, the most common pattern I've noticed is in Large Text support. It often doesn't exist, or if support does happen, it is often not in a readable way.

elements.text: Yeah, as a low vision user, the most common pattern I've noticed is in Large Text support. It often doesn't exist, or if support does happen, it is often not in a readable way.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think sometimes when developers make assumptions about what I need they can sometimes miss the mark. Just because I have low vision doesn't mean I need a totally separate design. When I see apps present a totally different design for VoiceOver users, I am always a bit disappointed. We have so many tools to make almost any design accessible, and people want to enjoy those experiences similarly to how their able bodied friends and peers are experiencing them. Implement APIs to support built in settings we've provided instead, and you'll be headed in the right direction

messages.text:
<@U03J4D1FEP6> asked
> For third party apps that are clearly at least making an effort to be accessible, what are the most common accessibility omissions or errors do you see developers making?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"For third party apps that are clearly at least making an effort to be accessible, what are the most common accessibility omissions or errors do you see developers making?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The most common issues I see when we do app audits are bad accessibility labels and improper groupings for VoiceOver users. Labels should be concise, and shouldn't include redundant information like the role (like the word button). And items should be grouped logically. The best advice I give developers is, think about how the information is "digested" visually. Is this group of labels/images conceptually one item when you look at it? Then it probably should be for VoiceOver users too. This isn't something we think about a lot, it's all implicit in the apps we use every day, but taking a step back to notice these things help a lot

<@U03JB2UUT46> asked
> How do header traits and levels work on macOS? I didn’t see a header rotor option available like on iOS.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How do header traits and levels work on macOS? I didn\u2019t see a header rotor option available like on iOS. "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So in VoiceOver on macOS the headings rotor will be found using the VoiceOver modifier keyboard shortcut + the U key. This will pop open the available rotors and if you're on an element which has a headings rotor you can use the left and right arrow keys to find it in the rotor menu. The headings rotor will include the level of the heading when announcing each heading.

<@U03HZ3N1QFP> asked
> Is it possible to emulate a switch control in either the Simulator or via an external Bluetooth Keyboard?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is it possible to emulate a switch control in either the Simulator or via an external Bluetooth Keyboard?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Great question. Yes, Switch Control can be configured to respond to external Bluetooth keyboard events!

Make sure your keyboard is paired to your iOS or iPadOS device, then head to Settings > Accessibility > Switch Control > Switches > Add New Switch. Here you get to choose the switch source, so tap External.

Each key on your keyboard could be its own switch, but you have to add them one by one. When you activate a key on your keyboard, Switch Control will ask you to name it and then assign it to an action, this helps you keep track of all the switches you add.

elements.text:
Great question. Yes, Switch Control can be configured to respond to external Bluetooth keyboard events!

Make sure your keyboard is paired to your iOS or iPadOS device, then head to Settings > Accessibility > Switch Control > Switches > Add New Switch. Here you get to choose the switch source, so tap External.

Each key on your keyboard could be its own switch, but you have to add them one by one. When you activate a key on your keyboard, Switch Control will ask you to name it and then assign it to an action, this helps you keep track of all the switches you add.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you're able, I recommend setting up at least three switches if you're using a keyboard with Switch Control: Select Item, Move to Next Item, and Move to Previous Item. For these you could use the space bar and arrow keys respectively!

elements.text: If you're able, I recommend setting up at least three switches if you're using a keyboard with Switch Control: Select Item, Move to Next Item, and Move to Previous Item. For these you could use the space bar and arrow keys respectively!

<@U03JEMN82JV> asked
> Can you give any advice to making a text view with a maximum character limit more accessible, especially with VoiceOver? Visually it shows a counter (eg: 90/100) and highlights text over the limit red.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can you give any advice to making a text view with a maximum character limit more accessible, especially with VoiceOver? Visually it shows a counter (eg: 90\/100) and highlights text over the limit red."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can override/set accessibilityValue on the text view to return the entire text.

elements.text: You can override/set accessibilityValue on the text view to return the entire text.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For the character limit, you could post an announcement notification when the user starts to go over the limit that says something like "character limit reached". You can also add a hint to the text field that conveys the max number of characters. Also make sure that your counter of 90/100 is an accessibility element, so that VO users can focus on it manually if they want to know the character count

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In SwiftUI & macOS 12 How can I move the voice over focus to a presented view?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Accessibility Focus State is gonna be the way go here! You can change the state value to true on an element and it will update VoiceOver focus to that element! <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/accessibilityfocusstate|https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/accessibilityfocusstate>

Does it make sense to change the focus when showing a new view in place of the old one on macOS? We have a list layout, clicking one of the items "pushes" a new view similar to a navigation controller. Currently VO loses focus and moves elsewhere.

elements.text: Does it make sense to change the focus when showing a new view in place of the old one on macOS? We have a list layout, clicking one of the items "pushes" a new view similar to a navigation controller. Currently VO loses focus and moves elsewhere.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So if voiceover is really not going where you want in this instance I think you could do that. I would warn about using this too often though because jumping around the voiceover focus can be very distracting. If its a totally custom navigation system than in that instance you probably want to either do that or trying to post a layout change notification. Usually though we either let the system framework and voiceover to decide where best to go, or if your UI has a popup or an alert thats a great way to use focus state.

> How are swipe buttons on list items regarded from a general discoverability aspect and then more specifically for VoiceOver?
> 
> I have a list UI that's more of a fake "tree view" with different types of content on most rows. There are correspondingly different swipe buttons on leading & trailing. Currently have no affordances hinting at them even for sighted users.

messages.text:
<@U03J1UX2CQK> asked
> When supporting dynamic type/large text sizes with custom fonts, is there a good way to limit the maximum size a font can be? Or is this just a bad idea in general?
> 
> Use case:
> While we are working on supporting dynamic type, we've noticed that we can support many of the larger sizes & all the smaller sizes. But the biggest sizes cause some pretty serious layout breaks throughout & it's going to take us a while to chase them all down + QA. I'd love to roll out support for most sizes so my customers can use it earlier & those who need the largest type sizes can at least get partway there.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I suspect you’d want to use UIFontMetrics to help here

```- (UIFont *)scaledFontForFont:(UIFont *)font maximumPointSize:(CGFloat)maximumPointSize;```

elements.text: I suspect you’d want to use UIFontMetrics to help here

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_preformatted","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"- (UIFont *)scaledFontForFont:(UIFont *)font maximumPointSize:(CGFloat)maximumPointSize;"}],"border":0}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In general, we would like to NOT cap font sizes, however there are cases within the UI that are very hard to grow given constraints. In iOS and iPadOS we will often use UILargeContentViewer (UIKit/UILargeContentViewer.h) to allow a long press to show text that’s can’t grow well

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In your case, it sounds like it would be reasonable to roll out support for larger sizes and overtime work to adopt the largest sizes.

elements.text: In your case, it sounds like it would be reasonable to roll out support for larger sizes and overtime work to adopt the largest sizes.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I'd reiterate that it's really not recommended to cap text sizes, unless the UI literally cannot grow without being unreasonable (like nav bars and tab bars, in which case use large content viewer like Chris said). Limiting text sizes will significantly impede low vision users from using your app properly. Definitely support what you can for now, but I strongly encourage you to work towards supporting all the sizes rather than capping them to a specific value!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Eric! By “keyboard accessibility” here I’m not just referring to keyboard focus, but what happens inside a lazy grid when you press the arrow keys (or tab, actually.) Or are trying to multi-select within a grid (Shift + Arrow Key, or Shift + Option Key + Arrow Key).

`NSCollectionView` and `NSTableView` can give you this out of the box (and you can see it in Finder or other native apps.) But this kind of keyboard accessibility — plus selection state handing — isn’t available in SwiftUI out of the box as far as I can tell.

Hopefully that clarifies my question!

The increment/decrement equivalents are accessible by touch or keyboard on macOS…. Look up Mac VoiceOver’s “TrackPad Commander” feature for touch gestures.

To _increment_ with a slider on macOS, you can use unmodified arrow keys in most scenarios. If the user wants to override the default key handling and force an “increment” they’d first “interact with” slider (VO+Shift+Down) and then increment (VO+Up or VO+Right in LTR languages contexts)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Big question! If I'm reading this right, then I would start with making sure your design system is able to make all components accessible to the same level as the native platforms
Then you need to transmute those paradigms in your system to the native platforms
This is very similar to what we did with Unity accessibility plugins <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10151|https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10151>

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So there are Unity methods for everything from custom actions to dynamic type. Those get translated to the native iOS
Thanks! :slightly_smiling_face:

In addition to Chris' comments, I'll add:

> What accessibility standards/assistive technologies would you recommend to take into account while building a design system?
<https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/|WCAG> has a lot of really great guidelines. If your design system includes web technologies, there are automated tools to test some aspects of accessibility, like:

<https://github.com/dequelabs/axe-core>

These tools can be run in a CI pipeline, allowing you to catch and fix accessibility issues as early as possible.

As far as which assistive technologies to test, VoiceOver is a good one, since often (but not always) if a web app is accessible with VoiceOver it is also accessible with other assistive technologies. But you should still test others! Full Keyboard Access (and even general keyboard navigability) is a good one. Another one to test with is Voice Control.

As far as which assistive technologies to test, VoiceOver is a good one, since often (but not always) if a web app is accessible with VoiceOver it is also accessible with other assistive technologies. But you should still test others! Full Keyboard Access (and even general keyboard navigability) is a good one. Another one to test with is Voice Control.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you Tyler! I've just submitted another question precisely about automated testing solutions, just a second before seeing your reply! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thank you Tyler! I've just submitted another question precisely about automated testing solutions, just a second before seeing your reply!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Tyler
Great minds think alike :smile:

Also make sure your design system requirements account for the superset of all available accessibility features.

There are API equivalents for many of these, like `isReduceMotionEnabled` for native Apple platforms and `@media (prefers-reduced-motion)` in Web. Likewise `isDarkerSystemColorsEnabled` vs `@media (prefers-contrast: more)`

Not all features exist on all platforms though, so be sure to account for all in the design, and support the implementation where available.

Thank you!

> When adding support for dynamic type, are there any guidelines or recommendations on when it’s best to respect the system settings vs offering a screen scoped font size control?
> 
> For example reader apps such as Safari and Books offer independent font size controls vs Podcasts and Mail do not. 
> 
> The pattern I see is apps or features where reading content is the primary experience (which I personally have used vs changing the system wide setting) - but from my earlier example Mail could  also be classed a reader app :thinking_face:
> 
> Thank you!

For example reader apps such as Safari and Books offer independent font size controls vs Podcasts and Mail do not. 

The pattern I see is apps or features where reading content is the primary experience (which I personally have used vs changing the system wide setting) - but from my earlier example Mail could  also be classed a reader app "},{"type":"emoji","name":"thinking_face"},{"type":"text","text":"

Thank you!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Good question! I think your intuition is right here. For longer form reading content, some people prefer to adjust font size on the fly, as lighting conditions change or their eyes tire. For apps that are not for long form reading content, these controls are really not recommended in my opinion. As of iOS 15, we have per app settings where users can set font sizes per app, and they can be adjusted quickly with our control center module. So users already have a way to quickly adjust text sizes on the fly should they require it. Users are expecting to open your app and see the text size they have set globally (or per app if they've adjusted it), so adding a second control to your app just introduces unnecessary complexity

If you're finding it's not, please file a bug to us via Feedback Assistant. This is by design

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Thanks for the question!

One thing you could do is to make sure the section headers have "header" accessibility traits via `accessibilityAddTraits(.isHeader)`

The second thing you could do is check out the `accessibilityRotorEntry` API to provide custom rotors for VoiceOver. This can allow VoiceOver users navigate your app more efficiently.

<@U03J1UX2CQK> asked
> What are best practices for creating a VoiceOver experience for audio recording? Especially if that page includes things like countdown timers or textual prompts for the user?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What are best practices for creating a VoiceOver experience for audio recording? Especially if that page includes things like countdown timers or textual prompts for the user?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I'd recommend you use announcement notifications for your prompts and countdowns. We do this in the "Hey Siri" training flow. Basically, whenever there is a prompt, we post an announcement notification, wait for the announcement to finish, and then start the recording session. When the next prompt is being read, we pause the recording. You can find out when an announcement is finished reading via this notification: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiaccessibilityannouncementdidfinishnotification?language=objc>

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi, I‘m the developer of the iOS and macOS versions of Safe Exam Browser (SEB), which is a freeware, open source lockdown/kiosk browser for taking web-based tests/exams (usually provided by a learning management system or testing/e-assessment system). SEB actually supports all mentioned Single App Modes, including Guided Access (that was the first one I supported for BYOD), ASAM and Assessment Mode (AAC). The Mac version implemented its own single app kiosk mode, but now also supports Assessment Mode.

I'm planning a _parental dashboard_ app to accompany the kids' version. So that raises the question of the dashboard app being able to configure single app mode in the other app. Ideally, it would be able to toggle it on a different device.

messages.text: Accessibility APIs :thread::computer:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We made API so you can turn on and off certain accessibility features during Single App Modes. You should always provide accessibility features to those who need them. And my pro-tip is to turn off any accessibility features after an idle user timeout or between customer transactions to set up a clean state for each user.

elements.text: We made API so you can turn on and off certain accessibility features during Single App Modes. You should always provide accessibility features to those who need them. And my pro-tip is to turn off any accessibility features after an idle user timeout or between customer transactions to set up a clean state for each user.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From which iOS version are these API available?
`configureForGuidedAccess(features:enabled:completionHandler:)` was added in iOS 12.2!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Thomas, first turn on Guided Access in Settings > Accessibility > Guided Access. Then open the app which you want to lock on to. Then triple-click to perform the accessibility shortcut. Depending on your device, it may be the home button if it has one, or the sleep/wake button. This is where you configure options for Guided Access before you begin, and Time Limit is an option in this menu.

> Who uses "Automatic Assessment Configuration"? Do teachers comfortably use it or is it only for IT?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Who uses \"Automatic Assessment Configuration\"? Do teachers comfortably use it or is it only for IT?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Apps that implement the Automatic Assessment Configuration frameworks can create easy-to-use UI to enter a testing session for folks like teachers to use. We also offer wide-scale solutions for teachers managing a classroom full of devices called Apple Classroom.

elements.text: Apps that implement the Automatic Assessment Configuration frameworks can create easy-to-use UI to enter a testing session for folks like teachers to use. We also offer wide-scale solutions for teachers managing a classroom full of devices called Apple Classroom.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
There is a lot of information about this topic, more can be found at the link below and I recommend watching past WWDC sessions about assessment mode in particular if you are still interested.

<https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT206151>

attachments.fallback: Apple Support: What's new in Classroom
attachments.title: What's new in Classroom
attachments.text: Learn about the latest updates to Classroom for iPad and Classroom for Mac.

elements.text: There is a lot of information about this topic, more can be found at the link below and I recommend watching past WWDC sessions about assessment mode in particular if you are still interested.

messages.text: It’s been a real joy hanging out with you all and spreading accessibility knowledge about some unique technologies like Single App Mode. I hope you had as much fun as I did. We plan to keep the Q&A open a while longer if you still have questions, and if you’re already signed up, we have one last session of our Accessibility Design labs in just about an hour, maybe I’ll see you there! I hope you all had a fantastic WWDC22! :wave::skin-tone-3::sparkles:

messages.text:
<@U03HVD726JJ> asked
> In an iOS app, I have a status label in the UI but it's too long and changes too quickly to be appropriate for VoiceOver.
> Instead I want to announce the beginning and end of a long process, e.g "Preparing ...", "Completed ..." to VoiceOver (triggered by a user action so not out of the blue). What would be the API to trigger such announcements?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In an iOS app, I have a status label in the UI but it's too long and changes too quickly to be appropriate for VoiceOver.\nInstead I want to announce the beginning and end of a long process, e.g \"Preparing ...\", \"Completed ...\" to VoiceOver (triggered by a user action so not out of the blue). What would be the API to trigger such announcements?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: you can post an announcement notification using `<http://UIAccessibility.post|UIAccessibility.post>`, and passing in a notification type of announcement, and a string that you want to have spoken

elements.text: you can post an announcement notification using
, and passing in a notification type of announcement, and a string that you want to have spoken

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/1615194-uiaccessibilitypostnotification?language=objc>
<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiaccessibilityannouncementnotification?language=objc>
Perfect. Thanks!

messages.text:
<@U03JM9TRBB3> asked
> I'm building a drawing app using PencilKit. What kinds of things can I do to make it accessible using technologies like VoiceOver? Is PencilKit going to do a bunch of heavy lifting for me in a situation like this?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I'm building a drawing app using PencilKit. What kinds of things can I do to make it accessible using technologies like VoiceOver? Is PencilKit going to do a bunch of heavy lifting for me in a situation like this?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Any UI that you're getting from PencilKit should get AX for free, like the palette controls etc. As far as accessibility work for the canvas, you'll need to asses what your users are going to use your app for, and build in accommodations around those use cases. Maybe that's announcement notifications if you're doing some sort of guided drawing to tell people if they are on track. It's always good to talk to blind users of your app if you can, and see what feedback they have. If you have more specific questions, feel free to post a question on the developer forums and tag it with accessibility, as the lounge closes soon!

messages.text:
:gratitude-thank-you: Thank you for joining the Accessibility Digital Lounge at WWDC22 :bangbang:
We had a great week! Three sessions, a Community panel, Q&A, design and technical labs and more.

There were lots of great questions and comments. It's a highlight of the year to get to meet (some of you in person) during this week :handshake:

We hope to hear more from you over Feedbacks and the developer forums :pager:

Until next year! :infinity::heavy_plus_sign::rocket:
